This is a holder for 2 power supply "bricks".  Each compartment is 33 x 51 mm. The height of the holder is 75 mm but the power supplies can be longer than that. The slots in the front allow you to insert and remove the brick without fooling with the cord. One of my bricks has the power cord on the left, the other on the right so the compartments are mirror images of each other.  I have it mounted to the side of my desk with #6 x 1/2" screws. I have the power cord going down and the computer cord going up. The overall size is 145 x 39 x 75 mm.
I increased the perimeter print speed from 30 to 45, to speed it up, could have gone even higher I think, as it still took 4 hrs. I made this to help organize my desk.
files work with da vinci junior, I couldn't get the openSCAD version to work :( I found some open paths in the extrusion. This is my revision. I'll upload pix soon
Because Why not?
Sand down the walls a bit, or it will be very hard to get them to fit.

title: Pig on two inch trailer hitch cover

description.text: Shapespeare's pig stuck on a long 2" square insert for a trailer hitch cover. Has a 3/4" hole for a hitch pin. The original file was put through 3dslash.net to give it the pixelated look. Designed in 123D Design. In pink, of course. Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA
Makerbot replicator 2 in PLA at 230C. Two or three shells, 10% infill is plenty. Support needed.

author: stewardj

description.text:
One of my friends could not find any replacement valve (knob) for his radiator and ask me to make a "funny" one ("coloured if possible").  
I didn't find on thingiverse the exact size and shape that fit the original part, so I decided to design one.  
After creating it, I was trying to put the "+/-" symbols on top (to explain how to turn it to increase or decrease heat), and I found that it could be drawn as a smile (sort of clown face). I like it as is.
You don't need to print it with 100% infill (30% infill with 3 perimeters and 3 top/bottom layers is strong enough I guess)

comments.text: Old design maybe, but works just fine indeed. I can finally easily adjust my radiator again (store bought ones didnt fit, radiator is too old...)

title: Mk8 Extruder mount for Prusa i3 Rework
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This mount works with most makerbot style extruders with a cooling fan. For maximizing the stability, there are two clamps that hold the extruder motor body and the fan. The OpenScad source file is parametric, so you can adjust the dimensions to fit your extruder or X carriage. You will need:
  • Four M4x25mm screws
  • Four M4 Nuts (nylon nut is recommended)
  • Four M3x50mm screws
  • Four M3 Nuts (nylon nut is recommended)

The attached stl file was designed for cheap chinese GEEETECH Mk8 extruder. You may need to adjust some variable for your extruder. tol: adjust this value from 0.2 to 0.5 depend on your printer's setting
motor_mount_width: motor mounting bracket's width.
motor_size: width and height of your motor fan_mount_width, fan_mount_size: default value is designed for the 40mm fan. holes_offset: translate whole mounting holes
holes: mounting holes positions.

Mount to be wedged into the top and bottom plate of quadcopter frame. This mount was designed for the HS1177 Camera. It's commonly referred to as a 25x25mm fpv camera. Two versions: Light and reinforced. You probably don't need the reinforced one, that's mostly for horizontal stabilization but it's your choice. The mount is designed to break where it's holding the camera upon a hard impact. A cheap plastic part versus a $35 camera... I'd rather break the mount. Camera: DC5V~22V Plastic Case mini 600tvl Sony Super HAD CCD Super FPV Camera 2.8mm Lens Known to fit the following frames:
Emax Nighthawk 280
FoxtechFPV Grasshopper Hexacopter
ZMR 250 Don't have a 3D Printer? Support me and buy through Shapeways:
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/tenfpv

description.text: This is one of our earlier experiments in printing soft microstructures. It is a 12x12x12 tiling of 10-3-a pattern. Each cell is of size 2.5mm, and each rod is ~0.25mm thick. Special thanks to Prof. George Hart for explaining this pattern through email. Please see more 10-3-a pattern at http://www.georgehart.com/rp/10-3.html Video: https://youtu.be/-OvKyrUJCS4

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Going off the inspiration of the sine wave spoon rest from makinit, I started from scratch and designed a spoon holder with a "engineering" flare to it.  There's a small recess in the spoon part to catch the drips and I've added some holes and curves to the handle to give it that lightweight look.  
Enjoy
Print on side to reduce support material.  Acetone vapor smooth it (if abs) to give it that non-porous surface.

This is one of the patterns we found from our topological sweep algorithm. It does not have a name, so we call it using its index: pattern0050. It is quite soft. It is a 6x6x6 tiling with 5mm cells. Video: https://youtu.be/OVwNiaZ6kt0 Clarification: This pattern is known to be anisotropic, and it is not one of the final selected 6 elastic textures we proposed on "Elastic Textures" paper published in Siggraph 2015. It is purely designed to test the printers' capability of printing microstructures.

remixed_from.title: compact bowden extruder using jhead normal push-fit

description.text:
This remix uses a 1/8 pipe thread that can be drilled (or in the case of the e3dv6 pre drilled) to 4mm to allow a PTFE tube all the way to the drive gear.  
Please comment if you have any questions.

When drilling the brass fitting put a m4 screw down the top so you don't drill through the fittings grips. (PLA) You may want to heat up the 1/8 hole before screwing in the fitting this will make good threads and reduce the risk of cracking the part. The V2 is stronger around the fitting but may cause interference with the idler, print at your own risk leave a comment if it works.
EDIT:
Confirmed, the stronger one works fine.

comments.text: I see metric and standard playing together in your build.... That would drive me nuts... Do I grab a Phillips screwdriver or an hex key etc..
comments.author: Pyr3x

comments.text:
It's actually all metric, the only non metric part is the 1/8 pipe thread which is used because it can be easily drilled to 4mm. As for using. Philips and hex, well I use what I have lying around that fits the job,its not always easy to find metric parts.
P.S. I redid this part with a pivot to reduce the pressure on the filament, but I'm thinking of skipping that design and going for something with an adjustable idler that's easy to grip.

description.text:
This was designed for my beta version Smoothieboard. I have uploaded a stretched version to suit the X4 and X5 production models, however I do not have one of those boards so consider that model to be UNTESTED. If someone can print one and try it out for me that would be great =D  
Note it was intended to work with vertical connectors not plugable terminal blocks like I have seen on some boards. I have allowed a bit more clearance for the X4 X5 version, however I cant confirm if there is room for plugable terminal blocks until someone tries it for me.  
The slots in the lid should be over the drivers, the rising hot air is what will pull fresh air in at the back.

I printed it with 2 shells and 50% infill. Weighs about 85g I think with both the lid and the box.  
Carefully drill out the holes with a 2.5mm drill and then tap them M3.  
Be gentle tightening the screws, its only plastic!

I want to build a modular system that allows me to hang things on a straight rail mounted a few millimeters from the wall.  In my office at work, I have one of those hanging rail systems that allows me to attach a whiteboard, or book case, or whatever.  Well, I want that for the home.
This set of things slip over a straight piece of aluminum or steel and provide some mounting holes.  These jackets can be screwed into a wall or other surface, and provide a convenient attachment rail system.
There is an end cap, and a 'slip' jacket.  The end caps secure the end, and the slip jacket can secure a midpoint.
Of course, it's a base form, so once you have the thing mounted on the surface, you can construct various other things that can slide onto the rail as well.
This thing works with 1/8" X 3/4" aluminum by default.  The OpenScad is provided, so you can construct any size you like by just changing a couple of parameters.

1) Purchase and cut to length, some flat aluminum (or steel).
2) Print a couple of the 'slip' sleeves and slide them onto the rail
3) Print a couple of 'end cap' sleeves, and slide them onto either end of the rail.
4) Mount the whole fixture onto a surface, using the appropriate screws or adhesives (liquid nails might work)
5) Rejoice! You now have a nicely mounted rail which can be used to attach other things. If you do some mash ups, you could attach something like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6807 or hooks, or whatever.

title: Chylld's RapMan 3.x Corner Set in one STL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is one file with all 10 parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4398 laid out so as to be printable in one run. I figure not everyone would have the means to pile them on like this into one STL, so I did it. Picture mid-print is 18 hours into the print using Axon2 settings for green ABS. Sadly, those settings don't quite work for me, so I run the .bfb file through a php script for post-processing. My own personal 3D printing demon is to get through the first hour of a print. After that, I'm OK. So rather than try 10 1~3 hour prints, I wanted them to go all at once. Also, they are close enough that Axon2's raft is interlocking between the various parts, helping them to stay attached to the print bed (part of my problem overall).
I imported all 10 of his source STL files into Rhino3d and rotated and moved them to fit closely together without interfering.

comments.text: I got the print done in 33 hours and 32 minutes using my conservative axon2 settings. I'll 7zip and upload my gcode, too.

author: ottenjr

title: Portable Battery Case for IMR 18490 battery

description.text:
I love my ecig.  The one downside is having to cary batteries with me.  This battery case was made to help solve that problem!  
This case is as small as possible and quite sturdy.  In addition, it has two latches that make sure it closes tightly and securely.  It makes carrying extra batteries with you quite easy!

I printed this using my replicator 2 on high settings.  There are some very fine details (<0.1mm), so the more resolution you throw at it the better.  I would say not to go under 0.3mm resolution because then you would no longer have the latches!  
This took about 2h to print.

author: eggnot

description.text: EMPLOYEE KEY RING

Split this into 2 models so you can print the base with black filament and the logo in red, then glue it together.
Much easier than trying to paint it or switch filaments for those of us with a single extruder!
lipstick holder

UPDATE, I have got the OK to upload the drawings and other files needed to make this Extruder to the Universities' website. Not sure if in future I may upload the files to Thingiverse, but for now you can see most of the files here: http://www.pe.mw.tum.de/fileadmin/w00bft/www/zip/Konstruktionszeichnungen_Extruder.7z The list of files there isn't yet complete but I am working towards that. If I find time I may add a BOM and instructions as well, but for now I am very busy writing my thesis. Newest tests are very promising in regards to consistent Diameter. Currently its 2.9mm so the Die diameter may be increased a tiny bit. Very little diameter variations can be measured at the moment. Any current variations are due to manipulation of the not yet solid filament. Biggest drawback at the moment is the extrusion speed, which is still rather slow, but could easily be increased with a bigger motor. At the moment the motor spins at 35RPM and is extruding ABOUT 4cm per minute. Feel free to ask questions in the comment section, if I have time I will try to answer these as soon as possible. Update: Added a BOM in the downloads

comments.text:
Hello Dolcey, Sorry If I step in right here but I may have some answers for you. I built an Extruder based on this one (just a little bigger). At first I used a stepper motor with about 1,3 Nm (Size Nema 34 company Portescap) of torque which wasn't sufficent (may have something to to with me using an extrusion screw and not an auger). So I added a gearbox with a translation of 20:1. The Maximum Speed of such Motor usually is about 200 Upm so with a Gearbox you get 10 Upm max.
I did a little math an calculated that this equals more than enough melted polymer for a theoretical extrusion rate (498 cm/min for a 1,75 mm Filament). I know this obviously won't happen but I'd be satisfied even with a tenth of that ;).

comments.text: The problem with a precise torque calculation is that there are too many unknowns and also a high number of variables in this system. I assume you would need somewhere between 5-10Nm. As for speed, the motor I suggested in the link above is about twice as fast as the one I am currently using, but that is no guarantee that the filament will be extruded at twice the speed. I have no idea what kind of torque the Lyman extruder is producing though.

comments.text: If you are looking at 3d printing make sure you look at the melting temps you will need for printing some of these. Materials like plastic 2 liter bottles require a higher temp then nylon and in many case the printheads have issues at such temps. Many of the current printers can use nylon but it tends to be towards the end of the extreme and going much beyond that may require significant changes to the printheads

description.text:
This upgrade greatly improves the strength of the arm/frame coupling, preserving the frame in a crash.
When you crash hitting an arm it's easy to tear the nylon standoff thread, causing the bending of the battery or bottom decks and consequent damages.
The aluminum standoff provide efficient mechanical seal in case of impact, where the weak point will be reduced only to the arm.
Is mandatory that you use a central stock M3x8 nylon hex standoff.
The holder accepts two M3x8 hex alu standoff for 5mm wrench.
Search the item 24432K-ND on Digi-Key. In addition, the holder allows to fix in a very convenient location any KISS factory form ESC, such as the DYS SN20A. You can use or not the ESC cover.

comments.text: What version of Slic3r are you using? One of the older versions had a bug with 0% infill, but it works fine for me with the most recent version (1.0.0RC2).
comments.author: harrysauntie

comments.text: I am not sure what Slic3r is sorry. I am new to this is it another version of makerware?
comments.author: spencer

comments.text: Oh, sorry, I haven't used the makerware software myself. Slic3r is an open source slicer program (converts stl to gcode). It works well for things like this–it even has a 'vase' mode that would work perfectly for this. However, I'm sure there's a setting in makerware that would force infill off, I'm just not sure what it is. Maybe make sure support is turned off and see if there's an option to disable top and bottom shells.
comments.author: harrysauntie

comments.text: I got a really good print of this, but Im a little confused how I am supposed to knock out the middle supporting material.  Any tips?
comments.author: sparkdaddychad

comments.text: It is designed to be printed with 0% infill and 1 perimeter, so you shouldn't have to do any post processing after printing. Sorry I didn't copy over the instructions from the original thing this is customized from.
comments.author: sparkdaddychad

comments.text: Humm, well I am very knew to 3DP'ing so bear with me.  My print turned out like the blue picture above, more like a hockey puck.  Did I download the incorrect file or just not set something correctly?
comments.author: spencer

comments.text: It's a setting in your slicer. A lot of models that are supposed to be printed with a single wall (vases, bracelets, etc) are actually modeled as solid objects. This makes them compatible with a range of nozzle widths. If you're using Slic3r, set the infill fill density to 0%, the solid top/bottom layers to 0, and the minimum perimeters to 1. Take a look at the resulting gcode file to be sure that nothing is printed in the center of the bracelet.
comments.author: sparkdaddychad

comments.text: Gotcha, thank you very much for that explanation, very helpful.

He is not a gun.
Printed this on an Ultimaker 2, it came out very nicely. There is more iron giant coming, I'm in the process of modifying the torso for 3D printing.

Most of the parts print fine without any support on a flat surface, except the jaw. I printed this straight upwards as it sits on the model, then removed support. I then glued everything together with super glue.
The colours are a guideline. I used glow in the dark filament for the eyes, but you can use yellow or white or something similar. The silver parts can be grey if you don't have it, also.
I have also uploaded the head as a single file if that's easier. In the pictures, I am holding the 1.5x scale version which prints a little bit nicer.

description.text:
To protect the little quadcopter motors from those crashes, I've put together a Tough and Simple motor protector for my Argonaut AQ250 using 2204 2300KV motors. This should also fit any standard 2204 design motors. This might not be as tough as a carbon fibre motor protector, but at least it absorbs the initial impact... and then we just print out another one ;-) UPDATES:
19/05/2015 - New "Lightweight" Tough Motor Protector, for those conscious of the extra weight.
I printed these with 80% infill, but as it is so small and thin... I doubt it even uses infill.

author: robyciccarelli

title: XY Calibration Cross (130mm; suitable for small vernier caliper)

description.text: I wanted a basic XY calibration piece that would use the full extents of my small Mitutoyo vernier caliper (which opens up to about 134mm maximum), and not use much filament. The Z height of the piece is ideal for getting past the dimensional error of the first few layers you get when your first layer height is too small (so the following few layers come out slightly bigger due to the backpressure that has built up in the nozzle).

title: Self Aligning T-Nuts M4 and M5

description.text:
I use MK Aluminium Profiles made in Germany and the inside track is square. So some of the t-nuts here wouldn't work. Also I wanted something that self centers when tightening and can be inserted even if the ends of the profile are closed up.  
The "T-Nuts" use regular M4 & M5 nuts pressed in and are 10mm wide. The angles are at 45 degrees which means that as you tighten it its pushes against the sides forcing the screw in the middle of the opening.

The nut goes on the bottom as seen in the picture, and the screw cannot be much longer then the t-nut since it will push against the bottom of the profile track.  
The thickness of the t-nut is 7mm. I made it almost as thich as the depth of the track so I have more plastic on top when tightening, especially since the nuts are recessed in the plastic. I could shave off a mill or two eventually. Otherwise if you use the proper length screw so as to not tighten against the bottom of the track the t-nuts will self align and lock in place.   
Best thing is you can just pop them in the track without needing to slide them in from one end of another.  
I printed mine 100% infill to give it more strength.  
Let me know how it works out and if you need any changes to it.

author: DanLuc

title: Two Mods to Straight Metal Jacket

description.text:
When I saw WilliamAAdams' metal rail wall hanging system, I immediately thought of two little mods for it:
  • A clip that could be added after installation, to add support without having to slip it on from one end of the rail.
  • A support piece that leaves the top edge of the rail free, for something to slide along it without hitting anything short of the two extremities.
    • It's all OpenSCAD, so it didn't take much longer to think it than to do it, so that's what I went ahead and did. Kudos to WilliamAAdams for writing such a clean code base, by the way!

Refer to the original design for mounting instructions for the rail. The StraightClip part slips under the rail and is attached to the wall above and below. The StraightRail part slips under the rail and is attached to the wall twice below. GitHub repository:
https://github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/RailSystemAddOns

comments.text: Now that's way cool!  And I didn't even get to add the supportive fillet code yet!  You're too fast man.

comments.text: I kept the mods light, just difference'd out pieces of your existing parts... so it should be fairly simple to fold this fork back in, as it were. :-)

description.text: Created with Design Spark Mechanical http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical . Have a great day. "-)

Extension cable for the Replicator 2X heated build platform. Designed to allow the connectors to be above the floor of the chamber, so that you can remove the platform without needing to access the underside of the machine.
  • (Qty 1) Digikey WM7992-ND Molex SL Connector Header 4POS Vertical Through Hole
  • (Qty 1) Digikey WM4583-ND Molex SL Connector FFC Female 4POS .100 TIN
  • (Qty 1) Digikey WM1324-ND Connector Plug 2 Position .093
  • (Qty 1) Digikey WM1331-ND Connector Receptical 2 Position .093
  • (Qty 2) Digikey WM3731CT-ND Molex Connector Terminal .093 Female Tin 14-20AWG
  • (Qty 2) Digikey WM3729CT-ND Molex Connector Terminal Male Pin .093 Tin 14-18AWG
  • Wires of appropriate guage and length
    • A 4-position Molex SL connector isused for the thermocouple connector. The one I chose is not designed to be a connector at the end of a cable-- rather it is intended to be through hole soldered. Hence, the backshell, a means of mounting the connector at the end of the cable with appopriate strain releif. There is a cable-end housing that mates with these connectors (WM6676-ND) but it involves crimping individual pins. I wanted a solution that involved a manageable amount of mangling crimp pins with needle nose pliers, since most do not have the crimp tool. I thought it easier to solder the connector than deal with tiny crimp pins. The thermistor is 100k-Ohm, so I think that extending the wires a bit should not affect the accuracy of the temperature reading. Install the MALE molex connector on the end of the original heated build platform power wire. The extension cable provides the FEMALE connector, making a quick connect/disconnect for the power wire. Make sure you know what you're doing before you install this. I have not yet installed mine yet. Your mileage my vary. Proceed at your own risk.

Print the backshell, install connectors on wires.  I routed mine through some black tygon tubing to make it similar to the original HBP umbilical.   
I used acetone to seal the backshell.  (And kind of made a mess of things)  You might want to use another method.

comments.text:
Hey, this looks great!
Do you think you could post an editable 3d file? I need to make this longer to accommodate the 4 wires I have instead of 2 (I am running the HBP power and thermistor wires thru this cable extension housing.

remixed_from.author: WilliamAAdams
remixed_from.title: AtHome Horizontal Hoop Door Hanger Attachment

description.text: This is actually a mash up between this derived thing, and this other thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8356 The idea is that once you have a flat rail mounted against a surface, you'll want to attach various things to it. This thing combines a simple hoop with the slip fitting for the rail. With it attached to the rail, you can then hang a coat, or slip some tubing in there and do other stuff. Maybe it's a support for cabling, or curtain rod. Who knows. This thing does not have good support. It can benefit from having some fillet added to the standoff to make it really supportive. But, you can get the general idea.

1) Print a few of these out
2) Slide them onto the support rail before mounting the rail
3) Rejoice!

Hi, I work for Refunc. Refunc provides a better life for discarded materials, components, objects or spaces Operating on the boundaries of architecture, art and design we reshape old materials to new products. Design origins are found in the object itself, listening to its own composition, history or local and social context. We can start from a design, but prefer problems to play with, like extreme deadlines and non-existing budgets...
3D troubleshooting and creative improvisation with locally available waste materials lead the way to our often unpredictable results. We can not oversee all potential of the material, although we are getting quite experienced by now... Wherever you can find garbage, we do research and workshops on creative re-use, as recycling is not the answer to the questions of life, the universe and everything. Now we want you to play with the materials we use. Only on a small scale. You can play and create your own projects. Use your creativity with existing materials. The options are unlimited. I will try to upload a lot of models. In the beginning the collection will be small. The goal is to create a big collection to share with the world. We even use it as models to clients. I am curious what kind of other possibilities you come up with! Enjoy!

I Created the models in 3ds max. I used the right scales in the software. But when you load it in cura the scale is not always precise. So my advise is to always check the scale. You can print multiple models, Then the fun begins!
Use your creativity to make art! most people are not aware of the possibilities with re used materials. Now it is up to you to discover.

author: 1Point

description.text:
Hi, I work for Refunc. Refunc provides a better life for discarded materials, components, objects or spaces Operating on the boundaries of architecture, art and design we reshape old materials to new products. Design origins are found in the object itself, listening to its own composition, history or local and social context. We can start from a design, but prefer problems to play with, like extreme deadlines and non-existing budgets...
3D troubleshooting and creative improvisation with locally available waste materials lead the way to our often unpredictable results. We can not oversee all potential of the material, although we are getting quite experienced by now... Wherever you can find garbage, we do research and workshops on creative re-use, as recycling is not the answer to the questions of life, the universe and everything. Now we want you to play with the materials we use. Only on a small scale. You can play and create your own projects. Use your creativity with existing materials. The options are unlimited. I will try to upload a lot of models. In the beginning the collection will be small. The goal is to create a big collection to share with the world. We even use it as models to clients. I am curious what kind of other possibilities you come up with! Enjoy!

I Created the models in 3ds max. I used the right scales in the software. But when you load it in cura the scale is not always precise. So my advise is to always check the scale. You can print multiple models, Then the fun begins!
Use your creativity to make art! most people are not aware of the possibilities with re used materials. Now it is up to you to discover.
This is the maximal size of a printcraft print

author: Ruff

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1v32o9qrE33

First try to combine 3D ABS with other materials. Since i got few pieces PVC foam sheet (Komatex) buy any plastic sheet is useful. Is stronger than 3D only, but i miss the fancy machine finish. I've made it a little bit lower than others since 1 of power plug bolts is on original PSU not on the case. It could be a problem on some devices, you should check dimensions. Mine fit but without plastic bolt cover.

Using the following options: BlockLength = 10
Name = Khori Baker
BlockWidth = 2

This is a remix of the model "To revive a unicorn" made by one of the boys at a workshop at a afterschool programme for kids as part of the project "To revive a unicorn". The project explores 3D-printings ability to make art accessible to everyone, everywhere and become an everyday-experience,
as well as its capability to let people rework and remix art and find new purposes and contexts for art pieces. As part of the project I want to encourage you and everyone else to use this model in whatever way you can imagine - Remix it, hack it or just print it and use it as it is, for what you want. And I will highly appreciate you sharing photos, models and other documentation of what you might do whith it, both here and and on Instagram with the hastag #toreviveaunicorn. Thanks :)
